title: 112_s3420
content: The "Permanent Tax Relief Act" is cited as the short title for this Act. It includes a provision for the permanent extension of tax relief. The Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 and the Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003 are amended by removing specific sections. The Alternative Minimum Tax exemption amounts are increased permanently. The Alternative Minimum Tax exemption amounts are permanently increased for taxable years beginning in 2010 and 2011. Inflation adjustments will be made for dollar amounts in subsequent years. The Alternative Minimum Tax exemption amounts will be increased for taxable years starting after December 31, 2011, based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to limit the aggregate amount of credits allowed for the taxable year. This includes the taxpayer's regular tax liability reduced by the foreign tax credit and the tax imposed by section 55(a). Conforming amendments are made to the Adoption credit sections of the Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to limit the aggregate amount of credits allowed for the taxable year. Excess credits can be carried over to the succeeding taxable year. Amendments are made to various sections of the Code, including the Child tax credit. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to limit credits for the taxable year, with excess credits carried over. Section 25(e)(1)(C) is amended regarding the applicable tax limit for interest on certain home mortgages. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to limit credits for the taxable year, with excess credits carried over. Section 25(e)(1)(C) defines the applicable tax limit for various credits, including the savers' credit and residential energy efficient property credit. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to limit credits for the taxable year, with excess credits carried over. Section 25(e)(1)(C) defines the applicable tax limit for various credits, including the savers' credit and residential energy efficient property credit. Amendments are made to sections 30(c)(2) and 30B(g)(2) regarding personal credits for plug-in electric vehicles and alternative motor vehicles. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to limit credits for the taxable year, with excess credits carried over. Amendments are made to sections 30D(c)(2) and 55(c)(3) regarding personal credits for plug-in electric vehicles and foreign tax credits. The first-time home buyer credit for the District of Columbia allows for the carryforward of unused credit to the following taxable year. The amendments made by this subsection apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011. Repeal of estate and generation-skipping transfer taxes under SEC. 3. New section SEC. 2210 added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for termination of estate tax. SEC. 2210 of the Internal Revenue Code terminates the application of estate tax for decedents dying after the enactment of the Permanent Tax Relief Act, with exceptions for distributions from Qualified Domestic Trusts. Additionally, a new section, SEC. 2664, repeals the Generation-Skipping Transfer Tax. SEC. 2664 terminates the Generation-Skipping Transfer Tax for transfers after the Permanent Tax Relief Act. Conforming amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code. Sec. 2664 terminates the Generation-Skipping Transfer Tax for transfers after the Permanent Tax Relief Act, with exceptions for certain provisions. The amendments made by this section apply to estates of decedents dying and generation-skipping. The Generation-Skipping Transfer Tax ends for transfers after the Permanent Tax Relief Act, with exceptions for certain provisions. The changes apply to estates of decedents dying and generation-skipping. SEC. 4. MODIFICATIONS OF GIFT TAX. This section amends the computation of gift tax under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax imposed for each calendar year is based on the aggregate sum of taxable gifts, with a rate schedule determining the amount. The tentative tax to be computed is based on different income brackets, with varying percentages and fixed amounts for each bracket. For income over $100,000, the tax rates are as follows: $38,800 plus 32% of the excess over $150,000; $70,800 plus 34% of the excess over $250,000; and $155,800 plus 35% of the excess over $500,000. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to treat certain transfers in trust as taxable gifts unless the trust is wholly owned by the donor or donor's spouse. Lifetime gift exemption is adjusted to $5,000,000. Conforming amendments are made. The tax is to be computed at $5,000,000, with conforming amendments made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section apply to gifts made on or after the enactment of this Act. A transition rule is in place for the calendar year in which this title is enacted, treating it as two separate calendar years for tax purposes.
